Level walking on tracks and woodland paths along the line of an old railway. There is a signed diversion from the line at one point and there are also some muddy sections in cuttings.
Woodland paths and tracks some made road and pavements and some grassy hillside. The woodland paths can be quite muddy in wet conditions.

description: A pleasant walk in open countryside but on easy terrain. Good opportunities for bird watching. The return section is on a minor road but it has little traffic.
terrain: An easy walk around Loch Freuchie on farm tracks and minor roads.
Main paths, riverside and woodland paths and tracks. Some of the ground can be quite muddy in wet weather.

Walk: Scapa Flow and Loch of Ayre, St Mary's
terrain: Coastal path, a little overgrown, minor roads
Rough coastal path, poor underfoot for grade 1
Woodland paths and tracks and some tarmaced road. Some of the ground can be quite muddy in wet weather.

Walk: Bridgend Woods and the Woollen Mill
terrain: Good waymarked paths, boggy section which can be omitted.

Walk: West Avonside circuit and Knock Earth House, Strath Avon
terrain: Farm track and paths (livestock in fields), minor road

description: A circuit around Auchterarder, known as the Lang Toon due to the length of its high street. This walk includes the centre of town as well as the surrounding countryside.
terrain: Good paths and minor roads

Walk: Fairy Pool and Riverside walk, Glen Tanar
description: This delightful walk on the Glen Tanar estate combines forestry and farmland with a long, pretty riverside section. The walk is well waymarked and can be combined with the visitor centre which has more information on the wildlife to be found on the estate. There are toilets near the start and a charge for car parking.
terrain: Waymarked tracks and paths, no real uphill.

description: This easy-going circuit on forest tracks has excellent views over Loch Ard including the remains of a small crannog. A steep, but short, climb is rewarded with a typical Trossachs view of loch and mountains, especially good in the autumn colours.
terrain: Well graded forestry tracks and paths, no waymarking so map reading skills needed
Good footpath, usually dry

Walk: Loch Ossian circuit from Corrour Station
terrain: Good track, almost level, fairly long walk in a very remote location.

Walk: Three Distilleries walk, from Port Ellen
terrain: Metalled cycle path throughout - only short sections on road.

description: This waymarked walk climbs through Glenmulliach forest and on upwards to a moorland viewpoint overlooking Tomintoul and the surrounding hills. The return leg heads deeper into mixed woodland and passes a wildlife hide.
terrain: Waymarked path and tracks, steep with steps in places

Walk: Commando Memorial and High Bridge, Spean Bridge
terrain: Well made path suitable for some all-terrain baby buggies. Wooden bridges can be slippery, dogs must be kept on leads.
Tracks, paths and minor roads.
Good paths throughout.

Walk: The Hermitage and Braan Walk, Dunkeld
description: This varied walk is a real Perthshire classic. It begins through the beautiful wooded glen of the Hermitage, complete with picturesque follies and attractive waterfalls. The route then continues to visit the dramatic Rumbling Bridge before a return through more open countryside with attractive views. The Hermitage is owned by the National Trust for Scotland.
terrain: Clear waymarked paths, tracks and minor roads.

description: This pleasant circuit takes in a viewpoint popularised by Queen Victoria and a lovely valley walk with good views. The walk can also be completed from the centre of Tomintoul by walking the half km along the minor road to the start.
terrain: Paths, tracks and minor road, fairly flat.

description: A walk in along a bleak moorland track is amply rewarded when the fabulous views of Sandwood Bay come into view, perhaps the most beautiful beach in Britain. Spend time exploring the mile of golden sand and dunes, with rocky cliffs and a giant sea stack to complete the scene. Despite its popularity, Sandwood Bay never seems busy as the beach is big enough to absorb the visitors.
terrain: Level track with a couple of streams which are usually very easy to cross unless very wet.

description: This straightforward, waymarked walk through forestry plantations offers some fine views over Loch Eynort, with picnic benches. The climbs involved are fairly gradual.
terrain: Forest tracks throughout; some ascent. Waymarked.

Walk: Inver Walk and Pine Cone Point, Dunkeld
description: A pleasant, waymarked walk leads into the lower section of the Hermitage and offers a chance to detour up to Pine Cone Point - a modern folly with a fine view. The route then returns along the banks of the mighty River Tay, passing Neil Gow's Oak and through the hamlet of Inver.
terrain: Clear waymarked paths, tracks and minor roads.

description: This easy forestry circuit has great views over the core of the Trossachs, with its lochs and tree-clad hills. Part of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park, the route has fine views of Ben A'an across Loch Achray and also of Ben Venue, a popular peak above Loch Katrine.
terrain: Good forest tracks and paths, gentle climbs.
Steps to Smoo Cave then gravel track, and road with pavement.

Coastal paths and beach - steep descent to 2nd beach. Livestock and ground nesting birds - dogs must be tightly controlled - sheep have been driven off cliffs and birds have failed to raise young in this area due to badly controlled dogs.

Walk: Birnam Oak and the River Tay, Dunkeld
description: This waymarked walk visits the ancient Birnam Oak together with other remarkable trees along a lovely stretch of the River Tay. The route returns through the village of Birnam with beautiful historic buildings and a Beatrix Potter garden.
terrain: Clear waymarked paths, tracks and minor roads.

description: A circular walk following a forestry track climbing to a hidden lochan to the south of Loch Venachar. The return is made along the shores of the loch with fine views.
terrain: Forest tracks and private tarmac roads throughout
Beach, track and path through dunes
Riverside and field paths (muddy in places), roads with pavements.

Walk: Saligo Bay beach and arches, Rhinns of Islay
terrain: Dunes, beach and coastal path, care needed near cliffs and arch - farmer advises no dogs during lambing season (Apr - Jun)

description: This superb circuit follows the banks of the mighty River Tay upstream from Dunkeld, before returning down the opposite site. It takes in the magnificent ruined Cathedral as well as some remarkable trees - including the Mother Larch and Neil Gow's Oak. NOTE: Path is closed on north side of River from Dunkeld House Hotel to Jubilee bridge from 21 Feb - 22 Apr 2019 not possible to complete the circuit, you can walk the south section of riverbank.
terrain: Waymarked paths and tracks.
Minor road, farm tracks and paths.
Sandy beach, track over farmland (dogs must be under tight control). Burn flowing out over sands may require a paddle.
Good footpaths, tracks and tarred lane.
Waymarked route through croft pastures and high bracken in places.
Track then path, livestock - keep dogs under tight control
Good track by shore, return uses woodland paths with some ups and downs.

Walk: Loch of Lowes and the Fungarth, Dunkeld
description: This walk explores the rolling countryside on the north side of Dunkeld. The objective is the Scottish Wildlife Trust Reserve at the Loch of Lowes, with its hides (admission charge) overlooking its famed osprey eyrie.
terrain: Paths and country lanes through pastoral countryside. One very short section of busy road.
Waymarked route, with tracks, grassland, some rougher sections and a short stretch of beach.
Good paths, quiet roads, riverside sections.
Clear path with boardwalks, dogs not allowed in hides. Short walk to viewing platform accessible for wheelchairs.
Grassy track and informal path, can be a little wet.

Walk: Cargill's Leap and the Knockie, Blairgowrie
description: This varied circuit follows the River Ericht upstream with its waterfalls, woodlands and old mills. The return is over the Knockie, a viewpoint looking out over Blairgowrie to the Sidlaw hills beyond.
terrain: Marked paths, tracks and minor roads.
Waymarked trail on woodland paths with some up and down sections.

Walk: Lochmaddy and the Hut of the Shadows
terrain: Good path and track with return on the single track main road which is usually quiet.
Riverside paths - rough underfoot in places - together with a lengthy section along the old railway line.
Grassy track, some pathless sections. Occasional waymarkers, livestock and ground nesting birds - dogs under tight control.

description: This enjoyable loop starts through the dense forestry plantations of Drimmie Wood but this leads onto the lovely Tullyfergus estate on fine old drove roads with ponds, woods and wild flowers.
terrain: Marked paths and tracks.

Walk: Allt na Criche, near Fort Augustus
description: A short waymarked woodland walk with good views over Loch Ness - can be extended along the Great Glen Way.
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks; steep initial climb.
Waymarked path with one steep ascent and a narrow section on the edge of Loch Lomond
Easy track and minor road
Pathless coastal walking on dry turf, sandy beach and dunes with occasional waymarkers.

Walk: Ballygrant and the Lily Loch circuit
terrain: Tracks and good paths.

description: This is a straightforward walk on forest tracks and a lovely path alongside the River Oich. There is the chance of seeing red squirrels amongst the Scots pines.
terrain: Easy going, almost flat, walk on forest track and riverside path.
Waymarked clear path with up and down sections, some steep
Track then sandy beach for most of the walk
Cycle path and rough minor roads.

Walk: Ardblair Trail and Bluebell Woods, Blairgowrie
description: This fine circular walk from Blairgowrie takes in fertile countryside, a couple of attractive lochs and a wood which is carpeted with bluebells in early summer. The last part of the walk heads through housing to return to the centre of Blairgowrie.
terrain: Marked paths, tracks and minor roads.

Walk: Three lochs circuit, south Loch Ness
terrain: Straightforward walk through varied landscape on a mixture of path, track and minor road with some boggy sections.
Waymarked forest paths and tracks; slightly muddy in places
Surfaced and unsurfaced road, grassy tracks and aggregate footpath; wet or rough going in places.

description: Kinnoull Hill has fine woodlands and a dramatic clifftop escarpment above the Tay. It makes a grand setting for a cylindrical tower built as a folly. The whole walk makes an excellent circuit from Perth city centre.
terrain: Roads and woodland paths which can be a little muddy; good amount of ascent.

description: This circular walk offers great views from the shores of Loch Ness, and a chance to look for red squirrels and roe deer in the woods.
terrain: Woodland paths and forestry tracks; can be muddy in places after wet weather.
A steep grass/earth path punctuated with rocky outcrops.

description: This fine linear walk follows the banks of the mighty River Tay from Perth city centre out to Luncarty to the north. The return to Perth can be made by bus.
terrain: Flat, surfaced cycle track and riverside path, can be muddy in places.
The walk up to the viewpoint is on an uphill track; the circular section through the woods is on a rough but waymarked path
Clear, short grassy path, wet in places.
Grassy field margins, footpaths and farm tracks.

Walk: The Isla Way: Dufftown to Keith
terrain: Minor roads, tracks, good paths, one or two sections can be slightly overgrown in summer. 3km stretch along fast B9014 road with no verge.
Mostly quiet tarmac roads; some sections on grassy tracks and paths with stiles.

description: This excellent circular walk explores Moncreiffe Hill, a beautiful woodland managed by the  Woodland Trust, as well as visiting the summit with its grand views over Perth, the Ochils and Fife.
terrain: Waymarked woodland paths; can be muddy in places.

description: This short but spectacular walk takes in the must see sight of South Loch Ness - the Falls of Foyers, set in a dramatic gorge. The walk then continues down to the shores of Loch Ness for a short, quiet loop before returning to the cafe.
terrain: Steep paths with many steps, minor road and pebbly shores of Loch Ness.
Fine sandy beach
Good waymarked paths and tracks; short steep climb on first loop.
Woodland paths, tracks and minor roads.
Clear footpaths and forestry tracks.

description: A circular walk taking in the idyllic Bracklinn Falls, a very popular local beauty spot. Once over the bridge the route climbs through forestry before descending to the quiet upper glen, with a return by minor road.
terrain: Good path and track with some steps - walk to the Falls is suitable for some baby buggies. Care should be taken at the Falls where there are steep drops and slippery stones. Return along minor road.
Clear coastal path, farm track and minor road.

Walk: Isle of Flodaigh seals, off Benbecula
terrain: Farm track, then faint path and pathless coastal section.

description: Climb the ancient round tower in the heart of the pretty village of Abernethy before heading off on this short circular route around the local glen. The walk includes the optional ascent of Castle Law - the site of an iron age fort and a superb viewpoint.
terrain: Good clear paths; steep and rougher on Castle Law.
Clear coastal path which then becomes rougher and narrow near East Head.

description: The Corran ferry links two different worlds - the busy A82 and Fort William area with the peaceful retreat of Ardgour. This short circular walk makes for an enjoyable stroll through wonderfully scenic surroundings - though the latter part is along the verge of a busy road.
terrain: Minor roads and good tracks, but 700m on verge of main A861

description: An accessible circuit taking in part of the shore of Loch Leven, including the chance to take the ferry to the Castle, and then returning through Kinross.
terrain: Excellent paths and roadside pavement; suitable for wheelchairs and buggies
Streets and pavements. Route is partly marked with arrows on pavement.
Grassy track and sandy beach.

Walk: Ellemford bridge circuit, Abbey St Bathans
terrain: Short stretches of main road farm and woodland tracks and some open farm land. Some of the ground can be quite muddy in wet weather.

description: This straightforward walk leads through the stunning Ariundle Oakwoods, a surviving fragment of the great forest which once swathed much of Europe's western coastline.
terrain: Good waymarked forest tracks and paths.

description: An exploration of the old streets and lovely architecture in the City of Perth together with green spaces and the riverside.
terrain: City streets, pavements and paths

description: A short stroll through fine alder woodland managed by the Woodland Trust, feeling a world away from the busy tourist hub of Drumnadrochit. There used to be a footbridge giving access to the shores of Loch Ness, but now this optional extension involves crossing a river - possible only when water levels are low.
terrain: Woodland paths; the route can be flooded after heavy rains.

Walk: Callander to Falls of Leny circuit
description: The Falls of Leny provide an impressive target on this straightforward walk from Callander. Starting from the town centre the route follows the combined cycle-walkway along the old railway line following the river upstream and then returns through oak woodland before rejoining the cycle track.
terrain: Level cycle track and rougher woodland path
Tracks, minor roads and beach.

Walk: Rubha Aird a' Mhuile, nr Bornais
terrain: Mostly grassy track and peninsula; some shingle.

description: This simple walk follows a private road into the empty glens of the Ochils, with good views over two reservoirs.
terrain: Private tarmac road throughout; fair amount of ascent

description: A visit to the site of the ancient fort atop Craig Phadrig, the wooded hill that rises on the west side of Inverness. The short ascent reveals glorious views over the Beauly Firth.
terrain: Clear paths through woodland.

Walk: The Great Trossachs Path 2: Trossachs Pier to Callander
terrain: Waymarked tracks, shared mountain bike paths, and minor roads.
Forest tracks and waymarked paths throughout; there is a reasonable amount of ascent

Walk: River Ness and Caledonian Canal circuit, Inverness
terrain: Canal towpaths, roads and riverside paths.

Walk: Duff House and the Bridge of Alvah, Banff
terrain: Footpaths and tracks throughout.
Pavements and waterside walkways, roads to cross.
Clear, waymarked paths and tracks.

Walk: Jubilee Bridge and Stalker Castle, near Port Appin
terrain: Paths and pebbly shoreline together with the long wooden Jubilee bridge and boardwalk. The walk is level, however at very high tides the boardwalk and shoreline may not be passable.

Walk: Caledonian Canal and Dochgarroch Locks, Inverness
description: This easy walk follows the Caledonian Canal towpath from Inverness to the locks at Dochgarroch, returning on the far bank; there is usually plenty of activity on the water.
terrain: Canal towpaths.
Shore path (with some rough stones) then minor roads and new footpath.

description: An easy-going coastal walk taking in the headland beyond Port Appin with fine views over Lismore and out towards Mull.
terrain: Easy to follow track, path and minor road, fairly level throughout.

Walk: Dog Falls and Coire Loch, Glen Affric
description: A stunningly beautiful walk through the ancient Caledonian Pine Forest. A powerful waterfall in a dramatic rocky gorge, stunning natural woodland of pine of birch, a beautiful lochan and excellent views: everything you could wish for on a forest walk.
terrain: Clear, waymarked forest footpaths and tracks; rocky in places.
Pebble and sand beach then a grassy path climbing up to the churchyard. The optional path onward up the cliff is very rough, narrow and could be dangerous.
Easy walking on beach and grassy tracks on the machair
Town streets, minor roads, riverside paths.

description: A short, but steep, walk up through part of the Glasdrum Wood National Nature Reserve, renowned for its rich variety of plants, birds and butterflies. The walk has good views over the head of Loch Creran.
terrain: Clear paths through woodland with a long, steep section rewarded by good views.

description: This short but very popular circular walk leads through the old conifer and broadleaved woodland of Reelig Glen, boasting some of Britain's tallest trees.
terrain: Easy woodland paths throughout.
Farm paths, tracks and minor roads. Two short sections of path can be wet and somewhat overgrown, but both are passable or avoidable.

Walk: Cauldshiels Loch and the River Tweed, Melrose
terrain: Town streets, minor roads no pavements, riverside paths.

description: This walk follows a waymarked trail through the forest, leading up through a fine gorge. The return route follows tracks and paths to complete a circuit through the forest.
terrain: Forest tracks and paths.

Walk: Fraserburgh Bay and Waters of Philorth
terrain: Beach and dunes.
Aggregate footpaths and grassy paths.
Country paths and tracks and cliff top paths.

Walk: Fas na Cloiche and the Fairy Bridge, Glen Creran
terrain: Forest paths - muddy in places, and minor road.

description: Plodda Falls is the highest and most spectacular waterfall in the area, over forty metres high; they form the climax to this pleasant walk through a magnificent forest of Douglas Fir.
terrain: Good waymarked paths throughout.

Walk: St Combs Bay and the Strathbeg reserve
terrain: Beach, dunes and grassy path.
Aggregate footpaths, narrow woodland paths and metalled cyclepath

Walk: Norham Bridge and Milne Garden, Northam Bridge
terrain: Easy walking along mostly grassy riverside paths with return along tarmaced roads.
Quiet surfaced roads, farm tracks and earth footpaths.
Very good paths with some steps but mainly level.
Farm track then grassy clifftop path. Parts of the cliffs are unprotected so keep well back from the edge.
Quiet surfaced roads, earth paths and good farm tracks.
Waymarked paths and tracks, muddy in places.

Walk: River Affric and Am Meallan, Glen Affric
description: A very short walk, but in such beautiful surroundings that it cannot be omitted.
terrain: Waymarked paths, rocky in places with steps
Steep path with wooden steps down to beach. The path onto the fort is rougher with care needed.
Earth footpaths, woodland tracks and quiet minor road.

description: This pleasant and straightforward forestry walk visits a hilltop mast to gain some wide views over the Beauly area.
terrain: The route is not waymarked but follows forest tracks throughout, with some ascent.
Good paths, gentle up and down sections.

Walk: Brodick to Sannox - low level route
terrain: Good paths, tracks or roads throughout.
Earth footpaths and woodland tracks.

description: This waymarked forest circuit leads through the beautiful oakwoods of Glen Nant, once a hive of activity as charcoal burners produced fuel for the nearby Bonawe Furnace. There are views across to Ben Cruachan.
terrain: Waymarked paths through woodland.

Walk: River Beauly and Lovat Bridge circuit
description: A pleasant, level walk with lots of interest and good picnic spots along the River Beauly. Plenty of opportunity to watch the fishing on this popular section of the wide and picturesque river. The inland return route is peaceful and particularly good for spring flowers or autumn colours.
terrain: Easy to follow paths, tracks and minor roads with no hills
Country lanes, dune path and sandy beach.
Earth and grass paths and surfaced roads.
Earth/mud footpaths and farm tracks, particularly muddy where cattle have congregated. The return leg is along a surfaced road.

Walk: The Forest of Deer, near Fetterangus
terrain: Easy forestry tracks and minor road.
Easy walk on surfaced path, short section on road with pavement, suitable for baby buggies.

Walk: Glen Cloy and the Fairy Glen, Brodick
terrain: Earth paths, forestry tracks and surfaced roads.
Dunes, beach, boardwalk path and minor road.
Coastal path with some pavement sections, then tracks and paths through woods and fields. Some sections can flood resulting in temporary diversions; short sections can be wet.
Good, if occasionally boggy, footpath.
Paths and tracks throughout.
Easy walking, mostly grassy tracks along old railway line.

description: This walk explores the woodland paths above Carbisdale Castle overlooking the Kyle of Sutherland. It gives excellent views, passing the castle and a very attractive forest loch as well as the site of the Battle of Carbisdale.
terrain: Good but unsigned forest paths and tracks; some sections prone to becoming overgrown.

Walk: River Ayr Way 1: Glenbuck to Sorn
terrain: Well-made aggregate footpaths and surfaced roads including a section of the first tarmacadam road experiments!
Tracks, paths and minor roads; some sections can be muddy.

Walk: Cubbie Roo's Castle and The Taing, Wyre
terrain: Minor roads, fields with livestock, grassy coastal path.

Walk: Contin Forest and View Rock circuit, near Contin
description: Pretty, circular, forest walk through birch, pine and spruce woodland visiting View Rock. Keep your eyes peeled for the elusive wildcat which lives in the vast Torrachilty forest.
terrain: Waymarked forest footpaths.

description: Balblair Forest is on the hill slopes to the east of the Kyle of Sutherland; this easy forestry circuit offers excellent views across the Kyle to Carbisdale Castle and down the Dornoch Firth.
terrain: Good waymarked forest paths and tracks throughout.
Clear path, mostly level on old railway line, short section of road, with one crossing of busy A95.

Walk: River Ayr Way 2: Sorn to Stair
terrain: Well-made aggregate footpaths and surfaced roads.
Quiet minor roads, track, sandy beach.

description: This short but very popular walk descends through varied forestry down to the Blackwater River to visit the impressive Rogie Falls. The falls are well seen from a dramatic suspension bridge, whilst across the far side an artificial channel allows salmon to bypass the main cascade.
terrain: Waymarked forest footpaths, some rocky ground.
Steep but grassy ascent up hill. Return walk cuts through pasture land and then along edge of newly planted woodland; long grasses may make for wet feet after rain.
Clear path, minor road (no pavement), then paths and stony tracks, suitable for some off-road baby buggies. Most of the route is shared with the Sustrans cycle route.

Walk: River Ayr Way 3: Stair to Ayr
terrain: Well-made aggregate footpaths and surfaced roads.
Good forest tracks throughout, short pathless section.

description: Every step of this short circular walk is a delight, passing through beautiful woodland close to the banks of a dramatic foaming river. The river is crossed at each end of the walk by picturesque old stone bridges.
terrain: Waymarked path and track.
Good waymarked paths throughout.

Walk: Huntly Castle and the River Deveron
terrain: Roads with pavements, narrow riverside path which can be muddy.
Narrow path, can be very muddy at times
Forest tracks and minor road

Walk: Rogie and Contin forests circuit, near Contin
description: This enjoyable walk begins by visiting the popular but dramatic cascade of Rogie Falls. It then escapes the crowds by heading up into the attractive area of forestry beyond, with a loop linking up with Contin forestry car park and an attractive stretch of riverbank.
terrain: Good forest paths and tracks; slightly muddy in places.
Waymarked paths throughout, with steps.
All good paths, suitable for pushchairs.

Walk: Flanders Moss National Nature Reserve, near Kippen
terrain: Boardwalk path, viewing tower to climb

Walk: Holland Farm and Tor Ness, Stronsay
terrain: Grassy clifftop path, some tussocky sections; track and some boggy ground in fields.

description: Kilchurn Castle is a marvellously evocative ruin with a stunning setting on Loch Awe. Unsigned from road this short walk is a delight and ideal for a picnic on a fine summer's day.
terrain: Excellent path.

Walk: Ferry Wood and the Ord, Lairg
terrain: Both loops are on waymarked paths; the Ferry Wood route is laid out to All Abilities standard and should be suitable for wheelchairs and pushchairs.

description: Strone Hill woods are a fine remnant oakwood almost hidden by the surrounding forestry of Glen Lochy. There are two short waymarked trails; this delightful and very easy walk is a combination of both.
terrain: Excellent waymarked paths throughout.

description: This is a short walk providing historical, geological and wildlife interest. In good weather the mid point of the walk is a great place to picnic and gaze over the clear water in search of dolphins. In bad weather the bothy, now a small interpretative centre about the salmon station and Hugh Miller, provides good shelter.
terrain: Easy to follow and well-maintained path to the shore with some steep sections. The coastal section is through long grass or at low tide the route can be followed on the pebbly shore.
Waymarked forest path throughout; some steps.
Coastal and woodland paths, steep in places with steps. The route can be muddy at times.
Mix of grassy, woodland paths and some minor road.
Woodland paths, roads (some with no pavement).
Forest tracks and paths; muddy in places. There is an unbridged burn after the bothy which can be crossed on stones in dry conditions.

description: A straightforward short circular walk from the old fishing village of Avoch. The walk visits Ormond Castle - once an important medieval stronghold but later completely destroyed by Oliver Cromwell. Today the green mound offers excellent views back to the village and across the bay.
terrain: Easy to follow forest tracks and minor road, with short steeper path up to top of castle mound.
Clear woodland paths with steps and steep slopes in places.

Walk: Dun Ara and Glengorm Castle, near Tobermory
terrain: Mostly a grassy track, wet underfoot in places. The final very short ascent to Dun Ara is steep and rocky.

Walk: Drumlanrig Castle and Burnmouth Bridge circuit
terrain: Easy paths, tracks and minor road. Some paths shared with mountain bikes and very muddy in places after wet weather.
Good clear, some uphill and downhill sections; steep flight of stone steps to descend near the river.

Walk: Lecht Mine from the Well of Lecht
description: This pleasant, very short and easy walk visits the isolated site of the former Lecht Mine.
terrain: Clear path / grass track.
Tracks and grassy riverside paths.

description: An attractive short 'figure of eight' walk in native woodlands recently planted by the Tyndrum community. There are good views of the surrounding mountains on this easy walk which takes in the riverside and can be started from (or extended to) Tyndrum by following the West Highland Way south from the village.
terrain: Clear, narrow (unmarked) paths and tracks through woodland and along the riverside..

description: An easy walk up a delightful wooded glen, with two attractive waterfalls. The Fairy Glen was once the scene of a well-dressing ceremony, where the children of the village decorated a pool, next to a spring, with flowers. This was said to ensure that the fairies kept the water supply clean.
terrain: The walk follows a clear footpath throughout, with steps.
Easy forest track and path, fairly level.
Excellent path out to lighthouse. Optional rougher return route above the woods is rough and muddy in places.

description: Tomintoul is reputedly the highest village in the Highlands. This waymarked circular walk explores the immediate environs of the village, passing a bird hide, and gives some superb views towards the Cairngorms.
terrain: Excellent clear paths.
Easy level path, optional extension is steep but on good paths.

Walk: River Annan circuit: Annan and Brydekirk
terrain: Riverside paths and tracks; some sections can be extremely muddy.
Good track, short section of boggy paths near shoreline, good paths on return.

Walk: Hoddom Castle and the Repentance Tower
terrain: Wayparked paths and tracks, sometimes muddy in places.

Walk: Lyness Wartime Trail and Wee Fea hill, Hoy
terrain: Minor roads and track

Walk: Calgary Bay and the Art in Nature trail
terrain: Woodland path with wooden steps in places which can be slippery, narrow track along shore, muddy in places.
Road, track and rough path near waterfall.

Walk: Bessie's Hill and Castle O'er, near Eskdalemuir
terrain: Mostly forest tracks and minor roads. Some shorter sections of grassy forest path - muddy in places.
Minor road, farm tracks and paths, livestock in fields

description: Inveraray has a magnificent position on the shores of Loch Fyne. This walk explores the area around the town, taking in Inveraray Castle and its fine estate as a prelude to a long forest walk through the forest plantations above the loch.
terrain: Mostly good forest tracks. The walk is not waymarked.

Walk: Castle Hill and Mill Loch, Lochmaben
terrain: Mostly good paths, tracks and minor roads. Final section of track and path can be very muddy.

Excellent underfoot conditions - including carpet; mostly level, with some stairs. Although waymarked with yellow feet on the floor, care is needed with navigation as it is easy to become disorientated.

Walk: Barnaline Oakwoods and Avich Falls, near Dalavich
description: Dalavich has some fine remnant oakwoods overlooking Loch Awe. There are two waymarked trails here; our route describes both, taking in the old oakwoods first before returning to the start and heading off to visit the Avich Falls.
terrain: Narrow woodland paths, steep in places, forest track and minor road.

description: Ord Hill is a forested ridge on the Black Isle, just across the Kessock Bridge and overlooking Inverness. There are two waymarked routes from a car park on the northwest side of the hill. This route makes use of some of these paths but begins from the larger car park on the north side of the A9.
terrain: Good waymarked forest paths and tracks; some ascent is involved.
Mostly good paths, tracks and minor roads.

description: This waymarked walk heads down to the shores of Loch Awe, passing the remains of a crannog, before climbing up past a waterfall through MacKenzie's Grove with its giant Douglas Fir trees.
terrain: Waymarked forest paths throughout.

Walk: Cnoc Croit na Maoile (Ord Hill), Muir of Ord
description: A short but at times fairly steep out-and-back ascent through open woodland and heather moorland to the trig point on Cnoc Croit na Maoile. The summit offers spectacular views over the Black Isle, Cromarty and Beauly Firths to the east and the Affric mountains to the west.
terrain: A waymarked route on forestry tracks and clear paths. Uphill section is fairly steep with some boggy going.

Walk: Forth and Clyde Canal: Bowling to Stockingfield Jcn
terrain: Variable grade surfaced towpath

Walk: Eskrigg Nature Reserve circuit from Lockerbie
terrain: Minor roads, tracks, grassy field and woodland paths. Muddy in places.
Well-made and broad path; suitable for bikes although with some short steep ascents.

description: Kilmartin Glen is said to be one of the richest areas in Europe for prehistoric remains, with fine chambered cairns, standing stones and cup and ring marked rocks. This walk links the most impressive of the monuments close to Kilmartin village.
terrain: Minor roads and paths.

description: An excellent circuit taking in the historic buildings of Dornoch, the world famous golf course, and the bracing sandy shore to the pier at Embo and back to Dornoch. This walk can be linked to the Dornoch Point walk by continuing along the shore instead of returning to the town at the Lifeboat Station.
terrain: Clear paths, tracks and minor roads with optional section along the beach.

Walk: Forth and Clyde Canal: Stockingfield Jcn to Kilsyth
terrain: Variable grade surfaced towpath
Roadwalking for much of the way; then fairly good paths with rocky section and final sandy beach.

description: This waymarked walk follows the delightful River Garry at first, with some good viewpoints, before returning on a forest track.
terrain: Waymarked route through woodland and riverside.

description: An excellent, and often breezy, coastal walk with good opportunities to spot sea birds, seals and many different shells. From the Point there are good views up the Dornoch Firth to the mountains beyond.
terrain: Beach and dune walk, near the Point care needs to be taken during incoming tides to ensure you are not cut off.
Rough woodland paths with some steep sections and steps, muddy in places.

Walk: Forth and Clyde Canal: Kilsyth to Falkirk
terrain: Variable grade surfaced towpath

Walk: Allt na Calliche Trail, near Invergarry
description: Well marked Forestry Commission walk which follows a delightful stream up through the forest, passing an attractive waterfall. The descent follows a track with more open views.
terrain: Waymarked route through forest; a fair amount of steep uphill is involved.
Path with very boggy section, track and minor road.
Good woodland paths.
Variable grade surfaced towpath

description: This walk explores the eastern part of the Loch Fleet National Nature Reserve. It has fine views, a spacious sandy beach, Scots pine woodland and great opportunities for bird-watching.
terrain: Minor road, paths and shoreline. The shore can be walked on a sandy beach for much of the way but at other times it crosses pebbles.
Level walking but the walk becomes boggy as it progresses.
Variable grade surfaced towpath

Walk: Lagg to Whiting Bay - alternative route
terrain: First shore section gives some rougher, wetter going; once turned inland, the route follows good tracks or minor roads, with a final descent on a woodland path.

description: This is a delightful riverside walk which can easily be extended to give a longer route if desired.
terrain: Path on the east side is well-made; the west bank is rougher will only a faint path but there is an alternative of walking along a minor road.

description: A beautiful exploration of Loch Fleet National Nature Reserve, a haven for birds, deer and pine martens. This circular walk takes in the shoreline which has good mountain views and the scots pine and mixed woodland.
terrain: Clear path, forestry track and pebbly shoreline.

Walk: Three Lochs Way: Helensburgh to Garelochhead
terrain: Good woodland and moorland path, then minor roads. The final descent to Garelochhead involves a path which crosses fencelines and is very boggy in patches, but is waymarked.

Walk: Union Canal: Ratho to Lochrin Basin
terrain: Variable grade surfaced towpath
Pavements, minor roads, tracks and woodland paths.

Walk: Tormore pier and quarry circuit, Fionnphort
terrain: Rough coastal path, flight of steps in quarry, stony  track, path boggy in places.

description: A quiet walk through forestry, visiting a tract of ancient, hidden oak woodland. Good chance to see wildflowers and wildlife. Take care with any ongoing forestry operations and respect signs.
terrain: Tracks and paths through forestry plantations and oakwood.
Well worn though rough path down to the Monument; optional continuation is on faint paths through the heather.

Walk: Iona Abbey, Dun I and the north end
terrain: Minor road, beach, optional steep climb to Dun I is grade 2 and muddy. Croftland used for grazing, dogs must be kept under tight control and walkers should stay on the path to head directly to the beach.
Good paths throughout; tarmac lane to finish.
The going is good on this section with dry paths, firm tracks and paved roads. There is one ascent on a road out of Beattock but otherwise it's fairly level.

Walk: Inverarnie Esker Trail, Littlemill, near Daviot
terrain: Clear waymarked paths, some short steep sections, narrow paths can be boggy.
Good going with dry paths, firm tracks and paved roads; long section of road walking on moderately busy road.

Walk: River Esk and Rowanburn Circuit, Canonbie
terrain: Grassy tracks, field paths, minor roads - not waymarked.

description: An easy and almost level walk using with stunning views up the length of Loch Lochy and across the Caledonian Canal and River Lochy to Ben Nevis. If Moy Bridge is left open then the walk would need to be extended by 3km in total to complete the circuit.
terrain: An easy walk on the canal towpath and minor road.

Walk: Wick Old Castle and the harbour
terrain: Clear paths or minor roads throughout; care is needed near the Castle as there are precipitous drops into the sea.
Very short and easy lochside walk to bird hide.
Surfaced paths, some steps, cafe and toilets at Pollok House and Burrell Collection
Marked grassy paths; care is needed near to unprotected cliff edges. Visitors are asked to keep to the paths to avoid crushing puffin burrows.
Excellent paths and pavements.

Walk: Grulin: in the shadow of An Sgurr
terrain: Track and path

Walk: Hoddom Castle to the Solway Firth
terrain: Apart from a few field crossings the whole stage is on good riverside paths and tracks. Both the walking and the route-finding are the easiest on the whole walk.
Pavements and good footpaths. By missing out the detour to the Cathedral (which involves steps) this would be a great walk for those with pushchairs.

description: Straightforward walk on a track through the attractive woodland beside Loch Arkaig. The walk visits a bothy before returning the same way.  Route closed 29 Jul - 15 Nov 2019 as White Bridge closed and no pedestrian access
terrain: Easy track throughout; the track is boggy on the final approach to the bothy.

Walk: Whaligoe Steps and the Cairn of Get
terrain: The path to the Cairn of Get is through rough pastures and is waymarked. The Whaligoe Steps are very steep with unprotected vertical drops into the sea; great care is needed.
Short easy walk on paths and tracks, gentle up and down.
Easy walking on minor roads, field paths and wood land tracks. The going is mostly firm underfoot with only a few damp spots.
Pavements, country lanes, footpaths and grassy tracks; one rough section with only faint path along coastline.
Rough tracks, minor road, and clear paths; burn crossing on stones.
Easy walking on minor roads, field paths and wood land tracks. The going is mostly firm underfoot with only a few damp spots.

Walk: Castletown: the Flagstone Trail and the Battery
terrain: Well-prepared trail, coastal track, optional woodland section can be very muddy.
Minor road, path over grazing land can be boggy

Walk: River Dee and Cambus o'May circuit, Ballater
description: This enjoyable waymarked circuit heads down Deeside to explore the strath to the east of Ballater. The highlight of the walk is the beautiful suspension footbridge at Camus o'May. The Cambus o' May footbridge is closed following flood damage so it is currently not possible to complete the circuit.
terrain: Waymarked footpaths throughout. Uneven in places and undulating on outward route; good cyclepath for the return leg.

description: An easy walk exploring the remains of the original settlement at Daingean. The walk has some nice views over Loch Garry and beyond.
terrain: Easy paths with some gentle uphill and downhill sections.
Minor road and large track for approach; old tracks which can be wet in the forestry parts. Fairly steep climb up to the Loch and descent back to Attadale.

Walk: Tomnaverie Stone Circle and Drummy Wood, Tarland
terrain: Waymarked field and woodland paths and tracks.
Steps down to reach the beach, then sandy beach

description: This circular walk heads around the edge of the Drummy Muir just outside Tarland. A spur ascends Knockargety Hill, site of an iron age fort and a good viewpoint.
terrain: Straightforward circuit, mostly on tracks and some paths. A little boggy in parts.
Roads and pavements, also many steps.
Woodland paths waymarked but muddy in places. There is a shorter all abilities path here as well.

Walk: River Spey and woodland walk, Boat of Garten
terrain: Grassy tracks and woodland paths.
Good track for most of the route; some short very boggy stretches on riverside path in the plantation.
Coastal and woodland paths, with some steps. Some sections can be muddy.
Roads and good tracks.
Rough and boggy paths with high cliffs in places, paths easy to follow.

Walk: Mull Coast to Coast - Killiechronan to Salen
terrain: Track then hill path; some sections are very boggy.
Quiet country lanes, old coach road and grassy paths.
Minor road and tracks, faint in places.

description: An exploration of the coastline that makes up the eastern side of Thurso Bay, this walk passes the ruinous Thurso Castle and has good views across to Scrabster, Dunnet Head and Hoy.
terrain: Fairly rough but grassy coastal path; alternative return route crosses farmland and is likely to be muddy
Waymarked forest tracks and path.
Pavement, cycle path and earth footpaths.
Unmarked forest paths and tracks. The route fords a small burn - easy in dry conditions, and has some steeper sections.
Pavements and good cliff-top paths
Good forest and moorland landrover tracks.

Walk: Inverawe and Loch Etive, near Taynuilt
terrain: Riverside path with some muddy stretches, tracks.

description: Easy waymarked walk with beautiful views across Loch Torridon. The walk includes a section of shoreline which is a good wildlife spotting area and then returns via woodland with  impressive rhododendrons.
terrain: Clear marked path and track with short section which can be wet underfoot - almost flat.
Waymarked forestry paths and tracks.

description: This forestry walk combines a visit to a fine series of waterfalls with a stroll along an ancient military road.
terrain: Easy waymarked paths and tracks; a fair amount of uphill.
Easy vehicle tracks throughout
Woodland paths and minor roads.
Indistinct footpath, boggy in places. Livestock grazing so dogs should be kept under tight control.

description: A gem of a walk following waymarked trails through ornamental woodland at the foot of Glen Coe.The picturesque and serene lochan and its wooded shores contrasts with the wild and dramatic mountains of the glen which are seen across it.
terrain: Easy waymarked paths.
Woodland paths, can be muddy in winter, tracks and a fairly steep final ascent path.

Walk: Langamull Beach and Kildavie, near Dervaig
terrain: Tracks and paths.

Walk: Buzzard Path, Beinn Eighe visitor centre
description: This short, attractive walk in the Beinn Eighe National Nature Reserve begins from the visitor centre - a great source of information. The walk has a good path through the pinewoods leading past several excellent sculptures but perhaps the greatest attraction is the superb views of Beinn Eighe and Slioch.
terrain: Well constructed path throughout, with one steep climb up stone steps.

Walk: Ardyne and the Clyde View walk
terrain: Waymarked paths and tracks, muddy in places. This route has a fair amount of ascent.
Good surfaced paths, some steps and short steep sections.
A straightforward waymarked route on forestry tracks and paths, no steep sections.
Good track.
Pavements and footpaths; a good number of steps.
Clear paths, some steep drops near the quarries, rough ground around first quarry which can be avoided.
Clear waymarked paths. The walk up the glen has many rocky steps and some unprotected drops.
Excellent path with some ascent; final few yards to the ruin are rougher.
Good track.

description: The Woodland Trail gives an excellent chance to enjoy the magnificent Caledonian pinewoods that led Beinn Eighe to be designated as Britain's first National Nature Reserve.
terrain: Well made, easy marked path around 100 metres of ascent.

description: This fairly level circuit explores the rivers Eachaig and Massan and the neighbouring natural woods and plantations.
terrain: Forestry tracks, minor roads, and riverside paths with some eroded sections where the path may be difficult to follow.
Easy paths made to 'Accessible for All' standards.
Good earth footpaths, pavements and surfaced roads.

description: This is the first part of the wild walk along the coast from Diabaig to Red Point (at the end of a minor road from Gairloch). Times are given for the return walk to Craig from Diabaig.
terrain: Excellent footpath throughout; the path crosses many flat slabs of rock in places.
Waymarked forest paths with a fairly steep ascent.
Forest track and path; the section around Rosal village is across grassy pastures where markers need to be followed closely.
Good earth footpaths and surfaced road.

Well-made footpaths - stony but suitable for most. Though the walking is relatively easy, the location is very exposed to the elements. In winter the paths are obliterated by snow and full winter hillwalking and mountaineering equipment is needed to walk out from the top station - with all the associated dangers including avalanche, cornice collapse, unstable snow, ice and rock.
Woodland and shore paths; the path has some extremely muddy patches in the woods.

Walk: John Brown's Memorial walk, Priesthill near Muirkirk
terrain: Rough and wet moorland path - faint in places.
Forest paths; waymarked but care needed to keep on the trail.

description: Strathy Point projects sharply out from the central section of Scotland's northern coastline. Visiting its lighthouse makes for a straightforward walk with some excellent coastal views including a dramatic arch. It is also a great place to watch for cetaceans, with whales and dolphins frequently seen in the summer months.
terrain: Tarmac road (private); optional variation on return across pathless but short-cropped grassy pastures.
Tracks and paths - sometimes muddy. Some short up and down sections.
Good footpaths, surfaced minor road and a section of the first tarmacadam road experiments!
Good footpaths and minor road for first loop; rougher with some short boggy sections on the path beyond Fasag.

description: The first stage of the Loch Lomond and Cowal Way is a varied cross-country walk crossing the southernmost finger of Cowal from Portavadie to Tighnabruaich with excellent views of Loch Fyne and the Kyles of Bute. The route takes in forestry, Ascog Loch and the ruins of a castle, farmland, the remains of a gunpowder mill, a golf course and the waterside village of Kames.
terrain: Forest tracks, paths (boggy in places), minor roads.
Good footpaths and surfaced minor road.
Easy sandy walking and dune path for northern section. Southern section has steeper path down to beach.
Good earth and grass footpaths and surfaced road.
Sandy beach (part may be inaccessible at high tide); return includes grassy paths, cycle path and a potentially muddier section.
Excellent wooden walkway to the tower, then optional return along flagstone trails which can be slippery or wet in places.
Good riverside cyclepath throughout.

Walk: Signal Rock and An Torr, Glencoe
description: One of the few short walks in Glencoe, this ramble explores the woodland in the central part of the Glen, and visits Signal Rock, where according to legend the signal was given to begin the Glencoe Massacre.
terrain: Good paths throughout; partially waymarked. There is some ascent and descent involved.
Waymarked forestry paths; the walk includes a sustained steep ascent with some steps.

Walk: Clyde Walkway 2: Cambuslang to Strathclyde Country Park
terrain: Footpaths with varied surfaces; some parts can be muddy. Pavements beside busy roads.
Mostly faint grassy tracks across machair. Short ascent to Ben Feall and one boggy section.
Pavement, tracks, woodland paths. Complex route in the second section of woodland.

Walk: Ballachulish Slate Quarries and Loch Leven, Ballachulish
description: This is really a combination of two very short and easy but contrasting walks. The first is a visit to the old Ballachulish slate quarries which supplied most of Scotland with slates for generations; after this look at industrial heritage the second part of the walk is a delightfully scenic stroll around the peninsula behind the Isles of Glencoe Hotel.
terrain: Extremely easy walk, mostly flat terrain on prepared paths.

description: A delightful waymarked walk up a sheltered glen to an attractive waterfall. The Flowerdale Glen was given its English name by the MacKenzies of Gairloch (the owners of the estate) after its impressive displays of wild flowers.
terrain: Mostly easy walking on waymarked paths, rougher near the falls.
Good earth and grass footpaths and surfaced road.
Waymarked woodland paths, track leading up to moorland.

description: This waymarked trail climbs high above the old Ballachulish Slate Quarries giving stunning views; the return walk is through dense forestry plantations but visits some hidden ruins.
terrain: Well constructed, waymarked trail. The initial climb above the quarries is steep.
Waymarked forestry paths with some ascent.

Walk: Clyde Walkway 4: Maudslie Bridge to New Lanark
terrain: Mix of tracks and paths; some rougher sections by the river bank.

Walk: Hogh Bay and Totronald RSPB reserve
terrain: Easy walking on sandy tracks and beach.
Forest tracks and paths; occasional steep gradients.

Walk: Strathaven, Sandford and Spectacle E'e falls
terrain: Pavements, grassy paths, narrow earth footpaths and farm tracks. Several stiles of varying stature as well as flights of wooden steps.
Grassy paths, sandy beaches, rough dunes.

Walk: Cammo Estate and River Almond walk, Cramond Brig
terrain: Earth footpaths, muddy in parts; section along minor road.

description: This pleasant circuit has good views over Mallaig harbour and across Loch Nevis to Knoydart. A good way to spent spare time whilst waiting for a ferry.
terrain: Well constructed paths; includes some ascent
Steep path then forestry tracks, partially waymarked.
Well-made construction tracks, a short section of asphalt and several horse and bike-friendly gates.
Pathless grassy machair; short rockier slope to the dun.

Walk: St Baldred's Cradle and Ravensheugh Sands
terrain: Rough paths, sandy beach, track. The route is not marked and the beach section is impassable at high tide.

description: The Silver Sands of Morar are a celebrated series of beautiful sandy beaches which pepper the coastline from Arisaig to Morar. Most are easily accessible from the roadside but this walk visits one of the least frequented beaches, crossing some wet ground on the way.
terrain: Easy path but very boggy in places

Walk: Roughpark and Doune of Invernochty, Bellabeg
terrain: Clear path, waymarked, optional ascent of castle is on steep grass.
Clear paths; rough in places with some potentially muddy patches.

description: Head north from Dunkeld to explore the quiet forestry trails to reach the loch at Mill Dam before returning through mature woodland overlooking the Tay and passing picturesque Polney Loch.
terrain: Forestry tracks, good paths, short section on roadside verge.
Mostly very quiet minor roads, with section of sandy track.

description: This short walk explores the fine Victorian resort town of Rothesay and includes a climb up to Canada Hill viewpoint.
terrain: Minor roads with short section on good track.
Woodland paths, steep in places, forest tracks, waymarked.
Made path with eroded surface

description: This walk follows a track along the west side of Bute with great views across the Kyles to Kames and Tighnabruaich in Cowal. The interest is in the various diversions from the track to visit the remains of several chambered cairns and the ruins of a chapel.
terrain: Fairly level track to Kilmichael. Visiting the archaeological remains involve detours from this uphill through woods and fields, on steeper paths with some muddy and overgrown sections.
Waymarked paths and tracks; short sections can be muddy

description: There are three waymarked forest walks from Fassfern; this route combines two of them to make an enjoyable, straightforward circuit.
terrain: Waymarked paths and tracks.
Level but muddy in places.
Woodland tracks and paths; muddy / slightly overgrown at times
Tracks and minor roads; optional section down to sandy beach. Final track can be very muddy.
Waymarked woodland and field paths.
Track, grass and pebble shore and grassy path. Finally tarred road / pavement.

Walk: Water of Ruchill and Cultybraggan, Comrie
terrain: Earth footpath beside river, minor roads and paths. Fairly short busier section on the B827.

Walk: Gruinard Bay and the Eas Dubh falls
description: This short walk combines a visit to a beautiful sandy beach with a brief but rough hike up a beautiful glen to reach an attractive waterfall.
terrain: The path up the glen can be boggy and indistinct in parts.
Woodland paths, track and minor road. Can be muddy in places.
Minor road, good path. Dogs are strongly discouraged.

description: This short and easy walk passes through beautiful ancient oak woodlands close to the shores of Loch Sunart.
terrain: Very pleasant grassy path through the oakwoods.

description: A pleasant and straightforward walk passing a loch with waterlilies and the ruins of Slaggan before reaching the sandy beach at Slaggan Bay. The walk can be extended to a long circuit by heading north along the coastline from the beach, round Greenstone Point and back by Opinon.
terrain: Good track throughout.

description: Ardentinny is a forestry village on the western shore of Loch Long. This scenic route links several of the trails from the Forestry car park, with some good views as well as the chance to spot forest birds and red squirrels from a wildlife hide. The route can be shortened or made easier by using different combinations of trails.
terrain: Good paths throughout. The Red trail has a steep climb, the Yellow trail a more gentle one.
Clear paths, steep steps near start, can be muddy in places.

description: This very short walk heads down through some beautiful remnants of the Atlantic oakwoods to a bay that was once an important harbour.
terrain: Easy paths through woodland.

Walk: Leith Hall parkland - Kirkhill and Pond circuit
terrain: Clear paths and tracks, 1st section around pond is suitable for buggies and some wheelchairs.

Minor roads, sandy beach, return across machair; no path. Grazing land and nesting birds so dogs should be under strict control, preferably on a lead - obey RSPB notices to avoid disturbing protected birds' nests.

Walk: Ard Airigh and the Garbh Eilean hide, Sunart Oakwoods
description: An easy short walk through beautiful ancient oak woodlands; the walk visits an excellent wildlife hide on the shores of Loch Sunart. This is a great place to watch for otters, whilst seals and herons are likely to be seen on most visits.
terrain: Easy woodland paths.

description: Rassal Ashwood is the most northerly ash woodland in Britain; the wood is at least 6,000 years old. This short walk makes a circuit around the woods using traces of a boggy path that can be a little overgrown with bracken in the summer.
terrain: The route is very indistinct and boggy in places; using a GPS can help stay on the path.
Clear, waymarked path, suitable for some all terrain buggies
Woodland and parkland paths; can be muddy in places.
Grassy machair and sandy beach.

description: A short walk to a little visited but beautiful sandy beach; the sands are covered when the tide is in so the walk is best done at low tide.
terrain: Boggy path to shore, then stepping stones. Depending on the state of the tide there may be rocks to scramble over to reach the beach.
Mostly tracks with some open fields and rockier coastal section. The route is often grazed by cattle.

Walk: Eas Mor and Loch Garbad, nr Kildonan
terrain: Well-made, accessible aggregate footpaths as far as the waterfall, then a rougher and slightly boggier footpath to the loch.
City pavements; many road crossings.

Walk: Applecross House and Walled Garden walks
description: This straightforward walk combines woodland, riverside, and seafront as it passes through the grounds of Applecross House. The walk begins and ends at the beautiful Walled Garden which has a cafe / restaurant. Many variations are possible as there is a wide range of signed paths across the estate.
terrain: Good paths and tracks throughout.
Well surfaced, waymarked, route with some up and down and steep first section.
Good paths and pavements with a fair amount of ascent.
Woodland paths, muddy in places.
Rough earth footpaths and well-made estate track. One shallow ford.

description: An enchanting short walk on an ancient path to two beautiful coral beaches.
terrain: The walk to the northerly beach follows an excellent path but the path to the southerly beach is very boggy towards the end.
Very short walk on woodland path. The path follows the rim of a deep gorge with an unprotected drop - great care is needed.
Rough earth footpaths, boggy in places.
Canal towpath throughout.

description: An easy linear walk between the beautiful sandy bays at Sand to the more pebbly Applecross Bay with great views over to Raasay, Skye and Rona. The walk can be done in either direction or as a return walk - the time and distance given are for one way.
terrain: Excellent, dry, well-graded footpath.

Walk: St Ninian's Cave from Kisdale, near Whithorn
terrain: Straightforward though slightly muddy path down to the shore, then pebbly shoreline to reach the cave. The cave may be inaccessible at very high tide.
Canal towpath throughout.
Good track, then rougher shoreline paths - can be covered at high tide.

Good coastal path, mostly surfaced but with a rougher section down to a rocky foreshore with steps. The alternative return is less clear and involves some muddy going, but can be omitted by retracing your steps.

Walk: Galloway House and Cruggleton Castle, by Garlieston
terrain: Woodland paths, field edges and cliff top. Can be slightly muddy in places.

Walk: Cramond Island and Cramond Brig, Cramond
terrain: Surfaced promenade, tidal causeway and earth path; can be muddy on the island.
Canal towpath throughout.

description: The singing sands is a magical place at any tide or weather. This, there and back, walk on tracks has a delightful first half next to the water and then through forestry plantation before emerging at the white sands.
terrain: Easy track throughout.
Waymarked path, some very muddy sections on the ascent through the woods. Forest track then tarmac road for the return.
Good woodland paths, level.

Walk: Culzean Castle Country Park, from Maidens
terrain: Beach, then varied clear paths, can be muddy in one or two spots. Short tidal section on rocky shore can be avoided.

Walk: Dalmeny Estate: Queensferry to Cramond Brig
terrain: Surfaced roads and pavement and aggregate footpaths.
Canal towpath throughout.

description: This interpretative trail brings the geology of the Moine Thrust to life as the path climbs past the exposed rocks and up onto the top of the Knockan Crag. From here there are spectacular views over Assynt. The trail includes sculptures and poetry as well as places to sit and a treasure hunt for younger children.
terrain: Easy to follow trail with some sections of rocky steps. As the path climbs to the top of the crag it can be exposed and therefore waterproofs and good footwear are needed.
Clear tracks, often wet paths, level.
Paths and minor roads; can be muddy at times.
Mostly aggregate tracks and earth forest paths, with a grassy path to the summit of Cockleroy. Short muddy section. Some steps.
Sandy beach, track and muddy riverside path. This latter section can be avoided by returning on the tarmac road.
Pavements or good paths throughout
Aggregate tracks and cycle path.

Walk: Achnabreck Cup and Ring carvings, Cairnbaan
terrain: Clear path and forestry track
Rough paths, a little wet in places, high bracken in summer in places.
Muddy heather track to the Brown Caterthun; clear path for the short ascent to the White Caterthun.
Tarmac lanes and landrover track.
Tracks and good paths which can be wet underfoot in a couple of places, short section of minor road.

Walk: North Glen Sannox pools and falls
terrain: Well made aggregate paths - rough boggier ground further up the glen.

description: This short walk to Port Ban, or the White Shore, skirts the northern side of Tarbert harbour with lovely views back over the boats and then reaches the small beach. There is an optional 0.5 km extension over rough ground to a viewpoint and back through the woods which is included on the map and GPS of this walk.
terrain: Rough path, can be boggy. Optional extension includes steep rough climb.
Quiet minor roads and tracks

description: This lovely short walk includes a visit to beautiful Clachtoll beach with its perfect sand and the crumbling iron-age broch of An Dun.
terrain: Close-cropped grassy coast to the broch; bouldery shore edge beyond then minor road.
Forestry tracks and dune path
Good tracks; can be wet on final approach to Tarbert Bay, grassy field to reach cemetery.
Surfaced path shared with cyclists, very minor road, clear path - can be muddy and prone to flooding (diversion provided) in winter.
Footpaths, pavements, many steps; can be muddy at times in places.

description: This forest walk climbs steeply through the trees, passing a fine waterfall and giving superb views across Glen Nevis. The first section of the walk is closed until end December 2017.
terrain: Well-marked footpath and tracks through the forest; steep ascent at first.

description: This short walk explores the coastline to the west of the stunningly situated village of Machrihanish. There are good sandy beaches, superb views across to Rathlinn island and Ireland, and great bird-watching opportunities.
terrain: Tracks to the Gauldrons; optional variant return can be wet underfoot
Surfaced path, rough sandy coastal path.
Forest tracks.

description: Culag Woods on the edge of Lochinver are owned and managed by a local community trust and have been made into an excellent facility for short family walks. There are some lovely views.
terrain: Informal woodland paths, rough underfoot.

Walk: Davaar Island and the Crucifixion Cave
description: Cross the long causeway that links Davaar Island to the mainland at low tides and explore a number of sea caves including one with a famous crucifixion painting, and then follow a track to the lighthouse at the northern most point. NOTE: This walk is only possible at low tide - tide times can be checked at the Tourist Information at the Pier in Campbeltown, allow plenty of time to return as the tide comes in fast and completely submerges the causeway.
terrain: Pebble and sand causeway only accessible at low tides, track and stony foreshore.
Surfaced path shared with cyclists, path and track at edge of golf course.
Green lane, minor road, main road with pavement (short section with no pavement). Waymarked.
Some sections on roads (care needed), tracks and clear paths, with some wet ground underfoot.

description: This easy walk explores Lower Glen Nevis, following the river bank and returning through the forest.
terrain: All abilities path for the first riverside section; easy paths and tracks throughout.

description: Achmelvich bay has a stunning and popular beach; this walk leads from it along a good path to visit a ruined old mill and hidden cove. There is also the option to hunt for a hidden hermit's 'castle'.
terrain: Good path to Alltan'abradhan. Optional extension to the hermit's castle is rough and pathless but short.

description: The Mull of Kintyre is the blunt southwestern headland that marks the end of Scotland. Immortalised in song by Paul McCartney, the Mull is a simple but steep tarmac walk with stunning views across to Ireland as well as along the coast.
terrain: Tarmac private road; very steep on the climb back up. Optional detour to memorial is on a muddy path.
Good paths, minor roads, tracks and pavement.
Streets, paths and tracks; climb to viewpoint is on rough and rocky path.

Walk: Neptune's Staircase and the Canal, Banavie
description: This easy-going walk follows the banks of the Caledonian Canal - built by Thomas Telford. The route takes in the entrance to the canal from the sea at Loch Linnhe, as well as the famous Neptune's Staircase - a spectacular flight of lochs.
terrain: Easy canal-side paths; care needed crossing busy road

Walk: Keil Caves, St Columba's Steps and Dunaverty
terrain: Tarmac road, sandy beach and grassy tracks. The ascent of Dunaverty is optional on a very rough path above steep drops.
Grassy paths next to deep water.
Easy waymarked paths, gentle uphill climb. Lochside section can flood - detour on road necessary.
Waymarked paths, tracks and minor roads, very wet underfoot in places. Shared cycle route for part.

Walk: Leitir Easaidh All-Abilities path, Little Assynt
description: There are few walks in the northwest set-up for wheelchairs (and those who don't want to get wet boots!) so Leitir Easaidh is all the more welcome. This trail visits two lochs with shelters and toilets, and has stunning views across this wild landscape to the surrounding mountains.
terrain: Excellent constructed path with easy gradients; suitable for wheelchairs and prams. Toilet facilities at two points on the walk.
Clear paths; short section on the shore is slightly rocky and could be covered at high tide.

Walk: Forest Walk up White Water, Glen Clova
terrain: Waymarked forest tracks and wide paths through woodland.
The walk follows a maze of woodland footpaths and tracks; muddy in places.
Good tracks and paths; slightly muddy in places on second part of Tay Bank.
Canal towpath, then minor roads, tracks and golf course paths.

description: This longish but straightforward forestry walk has excellent views towards Arran when it climbs above the treeline before descending towards Carradale and finally looping back up the glen.
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks
Steep climb on good path to Sutor viewpoint, then streets with pavements in Cromarty.
Minor roads, tracks and paths
Farm track, short pathless section through field, minor road.
Tracks, good woodland paths, sandy beach, tarmac lanes and pavements.
Paths, tracks and pavements, some muddy patches.

description: A short and easy walk to Rhue lighthouse with good views down Loch Broom and out to sea including to the Summer Isles. Can be combined with a walk up the road and track to the mast on Meall Mor to make a longer walk.
terrain: Short walk on uneven grassy path.
Riverside paths and minor road; can be a little muddy in places.

description: This final section of the Loch Lomond and Cowal Way links Arrochar on Loch Long with Inveruglas on Loch Lomond. An easy going walk with great views of the mountains. Could be done as a day walk with public transport. It also allows a link to be made between the Cowal Way and the West Highland Way. NOTE: Path currently closed until mid Apr 2018 between Arrochar and Tarbet use pavement on busy A83.
terrain: Good paths and tarred lane.

Walk: Plock of Kyle, Kyle of Lochalsh
description: The Plock of Kyle is the beautiful promontory west of Kyle of Lochalsh. The road to the Skye Bridge crosses its southern shores, but away from the road the Plock is a wonderful place to explore, with wild flower meadows, native woodland, a series of hidden rocky coves and a fine viewpoint. The Plock is also rich in wildlife, and this is an excellent place to look for otters. Whilst the directions may seem complex due to the many paths, the exact route taken matters little - the Plock is a great place to explore. It is owned by the Kyle and Lochalsh Community Trust who have developed access for the benefit of locals and visitors alike.
terrain: Straightforward walking; the short loop near the start  is an all-abilities path; parts of the other paths are less formal and can be boggy in places.

Walk: Kintyre Way Stage 1: Tarbert to Skipness
terrain: Waymarked paths and tracks, boggy in places.
Woodland and riverside path, sometimes muddy, minor road, short section without pavement.
Waymarked tracks and woodland paths.

Walk: Lael Forest Garden and forest walk
description: An easy and pleasant walk taking in the Lael Forest Garden with its 200 different tree species together with a longer plantation section with waterfalls.
terrain: Clear woodland paths and tracks with some ascent/descent, the latter with steps.
Metalled road and good aggregate footpaths, rougher further up the glen. Large stepping stones across Sannox Burn.
Clear, waymarked paths, riverside can be muddy at times.

description: This short walk to a beautiful and secluded coral beach. It makes a great place to watch for wildlife or just enjoy the fine setting.
terrain: Track then good path, with rocky steps down to beach.

description: Test your head for heights on the bridge and new viewing platform over the dramatic gorge while the water surges many metres below your feet. The surrounding walk has spectacular views of waterfalls and the open countryside towards Loch Broom.
terrain: Clear paths, steep in sections, the second half of the walk is accessible for wheelchair users and buggies.
Good aggregate footpaths and sandy tracks. Large stepping stones across Sannox Burn.
Paths and tracks through parkland and woodland; can be a little muddy at times.
Waymarked woodland paths, steep short climb to summit.
Mostly waymarked paths, tracks and grassy fields.

description: This truly stunning short circular walk from Plockton leads through fine coastal woodland with picturesque views across Loch Carron, visiting Duncraig Castle.
terrain: Clear but rugged paths, fair amount of up and down.

Walk: Kintyre Way Stage 4: Tayinloan to Carradale
terrain: Sandy shore, clear paths, and forestry tracks.
Clear woodland paths, can be muddy in winter.
Good farm tracks and grassy footpaths.
Mostly good paths; short very boggy stretch by Threipmuir reservoir.
Good forest paths, then rockier, rougher section down by the shore.
Sandy beach, dune and woodland paths.
Good tracks and minor road.
Waymarked paths.

Walk: Kintyre Way Stage 6: Campbeltown to Southend
terrain: Tarmac minor road for much of the way; grassy tracks and paths on the shoreline section.
Clear forestry paths.
Tracks and paths to coast, then dune paths and sandy beach
Dune paths and sandy beach.

description: This idyllic short walk heads round a beautiful section of coastline, with wonderful views throughout. There is a good chance of seeing seals or otters.
terrain: Waymarked footpath; one rougher section at back of one bay.
Riverside paths, muddy or slippery at times, rough with steps. Also woodland paths, cyclepath and pavements.
Woodland paths, rough and boggy in places.
Good forest tracks and paths throughout.

Walk: Loch Scalpaidh, near Kyle of Lochalsh
description: A short walk to a little visited and extremely peaceful freshwater loch, a quiet haven just a stone's throw from the busy A87 road.
terrain: Good path throughout, initially steep.
Sandy beach
Sandy beach, narrow and rough path through dunes, surfaced path between golf courses.
Clear woodland path, some very muddy patches
Sandy beach, salt marsh and woodland paths. The walk may not be possible at high tide.
Tracks and paths; Satur's woodland path is rough underfoot.

description: This short taster of Gigha visits through Achamore Gardens (entrance fee) where you can spend time exploring the semi-tropical planting. It then climbs up past an ancient standing stone and to the top of a small hill with rougher going but great views.
terrain: Minor roads, tracks and pathless fields (can be muddy).

Walk: Tentsmuir Point - forest and dunes, near Leuchars
terrain: Woodland paths, dunes, level forestry track.
Clear paths, care needed on golf course, roads with pavements.

Walk: St Andrews - Town and Gown walk
terrain: Pavements or paths throughout.
Clear paths and shared cycleway, road crossings, and short section with no pavement.
Paths, dunes and sandy beaches.

Walk: Barony circuit and the Great Map of Scotland, Eddleston
terrain: Undulating woodland and field paths, tracks and minor roads.

Walk: Gigha north end and the twin beaches
description: The north end of Gigha sees fewer visitors than further south. The gems of this part of the island are the Twin Beaches; the walk visits these as well as the North Cairn and the summit views of Cnoc nan Gobhar. The walk can be made into a short one by cycling or driving to a layby below Cnoc nan Gobhar.
terrain: Long road walk to the north end (can be cycled); then three short walks, muddy in places
Woodland paths with steps, steep ascents and descents. Some sections after the tower are rougher and can be slippery.

Walk: Creag Bhan and the Old Mill
description: Creag Bhan is the highest summit on Gigha. Its diminutive 101 metres of height may seem puny, but the summit view surpasses that of many a Munro. The walk also visits an old mill.
terrain: Road, sometimes muddy track and a winding hill path, rocky near the summit.

Walk: Dean Village and the Galleries of Modern Art
terrain: Roads, pavements and riverside path; long flights of steps.
Woodland footpaths, rough underfoot in places.
Paths and tracks through the woods, muddy in places. Great care is needed near the edge of the gorge. Short section of minor road.

Walk: Cuddyport beach and the quernstone quarry
description: This takes you to the breathtakingly beautiful bay at Cuddyport. This small sandy beach is an idyllic spot on a fine summers day. The walk also gives the chance to search for the remains of a quernstone quarry.
terrain: Minor road, track and path, scramble over rocks to the quernstone quarry.
Surfaced path for most of the walk. The exception is the short stretch on the south side of the river between the two Tongland bridges.

Walk: Stockbridge and the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh
terrain: Roads, pavements and parkland paths.

description: An easy circuit from Evanton which visits the shores of the Cromarty Firth as well as Kiltearn Church.
terrain: Quiet roads, paths and tracks. Short, wetter section by shore can be inaccessible at very high tide.

description: All walkers travelling along the A9 in this region will be keen to visit the prominent, strange monument atop the hills north of the road. They will be rewarded with extremely fine views on this straightforward climb through woodland.
terrain: Good woodland path with a fair amount of up and down.

description: This short but beautiful walk visits the impressive 13th century Skipness Castle and chapel before heading out to the stunning beach at Skipness Point. The return heads up a wooded dell beside a burn - this can be muddy but could be omitted if preferred.
terrain: Mostly on tracks; return through wooded dell is on narrow path, sometimes muddy.
Straightforward walking on the coastal footpath.
Mostly good paths, minor roads and pavements. Can be slightly muddy in places.

Walk: Castle O'Burrian and Bay of Tafts - Westray
terrain: Cliff top paths, tracks, beach and minor road.
Clear paths, golf course and minor road, with a short section of very steep path.
Clear woodland path, flat towpath and minor road. Steep in places.
Straightforward walking on the coastal footpath.

Walk: Threave Estate walk, near Castle Douglas
terrain: Waymarked paths, tracks and minor roads. Can be muddy in places.

Walk: Pierowall - Kirk, Castle and Beach, Westray
terrain: Tarmac roads, grassy tracks, rough ground near beach.

description: A visit to the site of some old gravel quarries behind doesn't sound very promising; nature has now taken over the old ground however, and the loch itself is very beautiful, particularly in the autumn months.
terrain: Clear paths throughout.

description: This short forestry circuit visits some fascinating archaeological remains including a hill-top Dun or iron-age fort with stunning views.
terrain: Waymarked forest tracks and paths, muddy in places. The ascent up to the Dun is very steep and can be slippery.

Walk: The Falls of Clyde classic, New Lanark
terrain: Clear path with many steps and lots of short up and down sections. Care should be taken with children on boardwalk section next to river or above cliffs. Suggested return route is muddy but you could return via the outward route.
Minor roads, tracks and woodland paths.
Grassy coast path, faint at times - can be very overgrown in parts in summer; return along tarmac road.
Forestry track, short path to final cairn.

description: This bracing walk climbs from Nigg Ferry over the impressive cliffs forming one half of the gateway to the Cromarty Firth. There are good views of Cromarty and the chance to spot dolphins in the sea below.
terrain: Minor road with very steep initial section, and grassy coast path which can be muddy in places.
Well waymarked forestry paths including steep ascents and descents on wooden steps.

description: Gleann Lichd is a quintessential wild Highland glen. There are few easy walks in the Kintail area, but this glen has a simple track; the walk up the glen can be made as short as you like.
terrain: The walk follows a simple track throughout.
Canal towpaths and tracks

Walk: Clints of Dromore Inbye, Fleet Valley
terrain: Mostly good tracks, short section of grassy path and boardwalk.

Walk: John o'Groats Trail: Culbokie to Alness
terrain: Mostly minor roads and surfaced cycle path; a short section follows a pavement and then the verge of the busy A9. Short section on a woodland track.

description: A good linear walk along the coast between the pretty seaboard villages to Rockfield. Along the way there are impressively sculpted rocks along the shore, the remains of salmon fishing stations and cliffs used by nesting seabirds.
